game_description: In the near future, what is the purpose of humanity? Activitude, the Virtual Labor System, is here to help. Your artisanal human companionship is still highly sought by AI clients. Strap on your headset. Find your calling. Pssst. . . Sure, you could function like a therapy dog to an AI in Bismarck and watch your work ratings climb, but don‚Äôt you yearn for something more: adventure, conflict, purpose? Escape behind the scenes of Activitude by putting on VR headsets to jump between realities, or vacuum up the world around you with your Activitude Brand Poly Cleanup Tool! Outrun Chaz, your manager, as he attempts to boot you out PERMANENTLY. Along the way, uncover the deeper story of Activitude‚Äôs evolution from VR start-up to the ‚Äúhuman purpose provider‚Äù it is today. Features ‚Ä¢ 50+ explorable virtual virtual realities ‚Ä¢ Edible virtual snacks in the break room ‚Ä¢ State of the art whale simulation ‚Ä¢ An artichoke screams at you
Languages: English, Chinese (Hong Kong), Chinese (Taiwan), French (France), German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Spanish (Mexico)
review_1: You should probably read this review before buying. So, this game has a little horror in it. If you have bad anxiety, I do not recommend this game. Of course, the game is also hilarious and fun, but once you get further in you have to stick to the more ‚Äúdystopian‚Äù part of the game that can give you a feeling that your about to get jump-scared. And if you don‚Äôt like being scolded by tall robots with no arms named ‚ÄúChaz‚Äù (which is remarkably close to ‚ÄúChad‚Äù) then this might be kinda hard to play. FOR THE DEVELOPERS: Hi! I love your game! But I have a suggestion- you should make a mode where you just get to peacefully try on the ‚Äúfun‚Äù headsets. You can make it so at the loading screen you choose your mode: ‚Äúregular‚Äù or ‚Äúpeaceful‚Äù of course, this is just a suggestion the game is fine as is!
review_2: VVR is hands down my all time favorite VR game. I could never play something like Resident Evil 4 because it's too scary for me, but VVR was just the right amount of unsettling. I did have to physically take off my headset a few times because I got scared like a wuss, but I quickly went back in because I knew nothing would come running at me, and the game always gave me time to compose myself and think about my next move. The fact that there were no cheap jump scares or chases is what allowed me to play this game, even though it had a few elements of horror. I'd say it's more akin to a mind-screwing thriller than a straight up creepy-girl-in-the-closet horror. The visuals, music, and voice acting were also amazing. As an office worker, I also found it awesome just how well they wrote Chaz's corporate lingo script, because he reminded me so much of one of my real managers. Most of the few bad reviews come from folks who didn't understand what to do in the game, but it's actually really intuitive if you think about it as your own jail break instead of a video game. Also, they could have easily looked up the guide or a playthrough to see how to get past it but instead they stop playing. If you're looking for a beginner friendly game with a dystopian story for you to uncover at your own pace, VVR is perfect for you. I seriously can't recommend this enough and I give massive props to the creators and anyone involved with its making.
